section.title: Creating the Component Dynamically Using Java
Details of Usage
section.para: All attributes except "value" are optional. The "value" attribute defines text to be represented. If you can use the "label" facet, you can even not use the "value" attribute.
Here is an example:
Use the "event" attribute to define an event for the represented element that triggers a menu appearance. An example of a menu appearance on a click can be seen below.
The <rich:dropDownMenu> "mode" attribute can be set to three possible parameters:
The standard form submission is performed and the page is completely refreshed.
An AJAX form submission is performed, and specified elements in the "reRender" attribute are rerendered.
The "action" and "actionListener" item's attributes are ignored. Menu items don't fire any submits themselves. The behavior is fully defined by the components nested inside items.
section.note: Note: As the <rich:dropDownMenu> component doesn't provide its own form, use it between <h:form> and </h:form> tags.
section.para: The "direction" and "jointPoint" attributes are used for defining aspects of menu appearance.
Possible values for the "direction" attribute are:

listitem.para: top-left - a menu attached to the top-right corner of the label
top-right - a menu attached to the top-left corner of the label
bottom-left - a menu attached to the bottom-right corner of the label
bottom-right - a menu attached to the bottom-left corner of the label

section.para: Possible values for the "jointPoint" attribute are:

listitem.para: tr - top-right point of the label element
tl - top-left point of the label element
br - bottom-right point of the label element
bl - bottom-left point of the label element

section.para: By default, the "direction" and "jointPoint" attributes are set to "auto".

To change the style peculiarities of the particular drop-down menus define your own style classes in the corresponding dropDownMenu attributes.
